node.title: 'No customer, no business': This salon will be checking you're double vaxxed
node.alt: Chiara Sianski in a beauty salon.
node.description: After being "so safe for so long" the message that COVID is coming has been drilled into Tasmanians. So how are businesses gearing up for the influx of visitors when borders reopen next week?
node.content:
["Tasmanian businesses are preparing for a flood of visitors to the state once borders reopen in a week.\u00a0", "While pub and club patrons are required to be double vaccinated, other businesses are making individual decisions about what rules they will have for customers.\u00a0", "Sharkra beauty salon in Hobart is one of the businesses which will ask their clients for a vaccine certificate upon entry.", "\"We are looking for proof of that double vaccination, just to ensure the safety of all of our clients and community,\" salon manager Chiara Sianski said.", "\"Because we're in close contact with our\u00a0clients every day, it is our livelihoods, so Sharkra wants to be seen as part of the solution moving forward.\"", "Ms Sianski said having a protected client base will also help reduce the impact on the\u00a0salon from cancellations due to illness, or the need for customers and staff members to quarantine.", "For small business owner Katinka Dineen, the build-up to Christmas is usually flat out in her Hobart gift shop.\u00a0", "With borders reopening, the festive season is even more hectic than usual.\u00a0", "\"We've been reviewing our COVID-safe plan, updating our cleaning schedule, and just making sure staff are aware that we perhaps need to be a bit more vigilant with making sure people are checking in upon entry,\" she said.\u00a0", "", "
Katinka Dineen says mask sales have increased as the Tasmanian border opening gets closer.(ABC News: Laura Beavis)
", "Ms Dineen said that while all her staff were fully vaccinated, the store would not mandate that customers were.\u00a0", "\"We're welcoming customers with open arms and we are making sure that customers check-in,\" she said.\u00a0", "\"We're really fortunate that our whole team is double vaccinated and that does give us an advantage with business continuity and just that peace of mind that if we do have casual contacts who are shopping with us that we won't need to quarantine, we'll just need to wait for a test to come back.\"", "Ms Dineen said reusable face mask sales had increased and customers were being proactive about capacity limits.", "\"We have had more customers checking whether or not they can enter the store or wait on the footpath when it's busy, so it's great to see that there is a strong community awareness behind that.\"\u00a0", "
Businesses urged to plan\u00a0
", "Rob Mallett, the executive officer of the Tasmanian Small Business Council, said a lot of businesses had been very apprehensive ahead of reopening.\u00a0", "\"I think that's because we've been so safe here for so long,\" he said.\u00a0", "\"Come December the 15th, we'll need things like a risk-management plan so every business will have to identify how do you intend to manage that risk of COVID either by a customer coming in or one of your staff getting it.\u00a0", "", "
Businesses have been reminded to review their COVID safety plans.(Flickr: James D Photography)
", "\"In the event that one of your staff gets it, it may mean that they cannot come back to work for up to a fortnight, which could be devastating for lots of businesses.\"\u00a0", "Mr Mallett said going through the process of working out the risk to individual businesses through the WorkSafe Tasmania safe workplaces framework would help alleviate concerns.\u00a0", "\"If you've got a business that has somebody who's in close contact, possibly a hairdresser or a beauty salon where you may have someone for up to two and a half hours face to face, I would imagine that many of those organisations will mandate masks for their staff,\" he said.\u00a0", "
'Extra layer of pressure' for businesses
", "Labor leader Rebecca White said the state government was \"pushing all the pressure back on businesses\".", "\"Whether it's for managing vaccinations in their own staff or vaccinated customers coming into their businesses,\" she said.\u00a0", "\"This is putting an extra layer of pressure on businesses at a busy time of the year, especially those who are in retail, hospitality, tourism, in December when they're seeing a lot more people come through the doors and borders about to open next week.\"\u00a0", "Tourism, Hospitality and Events Minister Sarah Courtney said businesses were ready.\u00a0", "\"We're working really closely with peak bodies as well as businesses themselves to make sure that they understand the rules and have their COVID safety plans ready to go,\" she said.\u00a0", "\"It is a timely reminder that businesses do need to review their COVID safety plan, they do need risk management plans in place because we are expecting to see COVID in this state\u00a0so businesses need to know what they're going to do when they do see a COVID case happen in their businesses.\"\u00a0", "
Taste ready to return
", "", "
The new-look Taste festival will have a capacity limit of 5,000 at any one time.(Facebook: Taste of Tasmania)
", "Set up for the Taste of Summer event has begun at Princes Wharf.", "Event chairman Jarrod Nation said he was very pleased that borders were opening next week.\u00a0", "\"We think that's\u00a0really exciting for tourism and [hospitality]\u00a0businesses that have been harshly done by COVID, we can't wait to see the visitors to our state, we can't wait to see the visitors coming through the door at the Taste of Summer,\" he said.\u00a0", "\"We'll be complying with the state regulations for vaccinations, we'd like love people here to move freely through the site, we'd love them to be able to dance to music on New Year's Eve and the double vaccination provides that opportunity to everyone coming here.\"", "The ticketed Taste of Summer will have a capacity of 5,000 people at any one time and a virtual queue system will be used.\u00a0", "Interstate purchases account for 32 per cent of ticket sales.", "Mr Nation said it had been challenging getting the event established during the pandemic.\u00a0", "\"This is Australia's largest food and drink festival, no-one's ever run an event like that during COVID times,\" he said.\u00a0", "\"We're confident the COVID safe plan, once it's approved by Public Health, will make everyone safe.\"", "", "
